qas.question: What type of buildings most prominently display the design aspects of the Gothic architectural style?
Prior to the 20th century, a Gothic cathedral was considered to be what type of building in the town in which it was constructed?
What is another name for the pointed arch?
What is an example of architectural technology that is seen in Gothic construction?
What is another example of architectural technology that is seen in Gothic construction?
What type of buildings most prominently hide the design aspects of the Gothic architectural style?
What is another name for the twisted arch?
What is an example of impossible technology that is seen in Gothic construction?
When was it typical that Gothic cathedrals were hidden?

context: While many secular buildings exist from the Late Middle Ages, it is in the buildings of <a0_0><b5_0>cathedrals and great churches<b5_0/><a0_0/> that Gothic architecture displays its pertinent structures and characteristics to the fullest advantage. A Gothic cathedral or abbey was, <b8_0>prior to the 20th century<b8_0/>, generally <a1_0>the landmark building<a1_0/> in its town, rising high above all the domestic structures and often surmounted by one or more towers and pinnacles and perhaps tall spires. These cathedrals were the skyscrapers of that day and would have been the largest buildings by far that Europeans would ever have seen. It is in the architecture of these Gothic churches that a unique combination of existing technologies established the emergence of a new building style. Those technologies were <a2_0><b6_0>the ogival<b6_0/><a2_0/> or pointed arch, <a3_0><b7_0>the ribbed vault<b7_0/><a3_0/>, and <a4_0>the buttress<a4_0/>.
